PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

MAY 10 1954
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

MEMBERSHIP VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How often did you visit? How many of them were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays, or other days? Mostly Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? We just visited any time.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (This is what the term "to make pollock" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Usually a cup of coffee and some cake.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "neats" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible; telling what the "neats" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in homes?

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

We were here 5 years before we had a school, and the school was not used for any purpose until 1919 when we had box socials and dances to raise money to buy an organ. So we always had Christmas trees and programs to which our parents could bring guests.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

The first winter there was only 3 families here and then everybody was pretty busy, and Sunday was the only leisure so there was not much base ball played but we did have an occasional base game.

9. When was your first community hall built? How large was it? What material was it made of?

A creamery was built in 1944 and was used for a hall.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The farmers took out the lumber and had it sawed. The building was used as a hall.

Was it built in the village or town or was it a country hall?

Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

We used this building for dances, box socials, parties, even church services during the winters. We used the school house for services and box socials and dances too.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Yes

How were babies and small children provided for? In homes there was always a bed and other places they fixed up beneath or beside.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

There seemed to be plenty barn room where dances the horses were put in neighbors barns and on snow the crowd would sit outside.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

King Reds, Crazy Reds.

Was there card playing for a prize?

No

What dances were popular? Fox step, waltz, square dance, Polka, French minuet, schottse, rye waltz.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Not often, the only times was some would not allow a dance the night of a church picnic or bazaar or any church function.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Not in our immediate community, but we were settled in such a way that it seemed each community was of the same church, so other district was of the same faith so that made matters easier.
